awd_titl_txt: The Mass-Radius Relation of Young Stars from K2
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern astronomy depends on theoretical models of the life cycles of stars.  These models are then used to suggest new ways to study planets around other stars and to determine our own Solar System compares with other planetary systems.  Their predictions can be tested by observing pairs of stars orbiting each other.  Their orbital speed reveals the masses of the stars, while the dimming produced when they eclipse each other reveals their sizes.  This team will study a large sample of very young eclipsing binary star systems in order to measure fundamental stellar properties.  Undergraduate students will be involved at all stages of the investigation.  The Principal Investigator (PI) will bring the scientific discovery process into his classroom, serving the national interest by promoting STEM education and improving the retention of members of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

Predictions from evolutionary models of pre-main sequence stars remain largely untested, especially for masses below that of the Sun.  The investigation will characterize 15 young eclipsing binary systems observed by K2 (the repurposed Kepler mission) in the Upper Scorpius star-forming region, measuring masses, radii, luminosities, temperatures, and magnetic field strengths.  The proposed program also will compare observed magnetic field strengths to the values required in new magnetized stellar evolutionary models.  The PI will use upper-level undergraduate classes in stellar astrophysics to test new experiential learning techniques and as a gateway for recruiting students to become involved in this research, joined by summer interns recruited from underrepresented/underserved populations at other institutions.  The on-campus research students will then serve the following year as peer mentors and role models.

por.por_cntn:
This program studied young star systems in which two stars are orbiting close together and periodically eclipse each other. By characterizing and modeling the eclipses and the orbits of the stars, it is possible to measure the masses and radii of the stars, which enable tests of how stars evolve over time. We identified a large number of such systems among the stars that were monitored by the K2 and TESS missions, and then obtained spectra that spanned each system’s orbital period that allowed us to measure the stars’ individual masses. We then combined those spectra with the light curves in order to estimate the stars’ radii, as well as obtaining additional spectra and brightness measurements at different wavelengths in order to estimate the stars’ intrinsic brightness and surface temperature.

Our results show that in at least some cases, young stars of a given mass and age are larger in radius and cooler in surface temperature than theoretical models would predict, though in such a way that the overall brightness does match. This indicates that energy does not escape from these stars as efficiently as expected, leading them to be puffier and cooler. One possible explanation could be that their magnetic fields interfere with energy transport out of the star, and we are pursuing observations to measure the stars’ surface magnetic fields to test if the level of discrepancy is correlated with the magnetic field strength.

We also identified numerous systems that show apparent dips in brightness that look like eclipses, but consist of only one star and do not have a binary companion that could cause eclipse. These systems have been hypothesized to have dust clouds in close orbit, locked in the same position relative to the star and orbiting in sync with the star’s rotation. However, we have shown that these systems are all rotating very quickly and nearly equator, and the observations are consistent with having bright spots near the poles of the stars. As the bright spots briefly rotate to the back side of the star and duck out of view, there is a brightness dip that appears equivalent to if another object had orbited in front and blocked light.

Our search also contributed to the identification and characterization of several young planetary systems where the planets periodically eclipse their host star. These systems are providing new context for the formation and evolution of planetary systems early in their lives.

Finally, several of the results from this program were discovered by undergraduate researchers from under-represented backgrounds, who were supported in paid summer internships (including some via the TAURUS program) to explore novel scientific questions and gain experience in scientific inquiry. These summer internships provide training in STEM that will lead to additional future career opportunities in both academia and the broader STEM field.
